results.title: Lesbian Vampires = Vampyros Lesbos
results.creator_credit: Jesus Franco, Karl Heinz Mannchen, Fenix Cooperative Cinematografica, Hispano-Allemande and Telecine
results.brief_description: Amidst psychedelic keyboard and sitar music comes the erotic horror story of a powerful lesbian vampire (Soledad Miranda). Linda (Ewa Stromberg), a lawyer, is having potent and erotic dreams that she can’t explain. Her work sends her to a small island where she meets the force behind her dreams and her life is taken over by the rule of the dark spirit world. Does she have the will to resist? Will her boyfriend and sympathetic psychiatrist get to her in time? A cult classic from the director of “Female Vampire”. Cast includes Susann Korda, Dennis Price, Paul Muller.

results.title: Les Zozos = the Deceivers
results.creator_credit: Pascal Thomas and Albina du Boisrouvray
results.brief_description:
In 1962, two teenage boys spend their weeks in a boarding school in a provincial town. They horse around, playing pranks, roughhousing with each other and climbing over the school’s walls to harass and tease the local girls. Their main interest in life is women; anything to do with them is pleasing to them. They scrape together the money for a trip to Sweden, and despite more difficulties than they anticipated, one of them succeeds in making love with a girl.

Credits: Producer, Albina du Boisrouvray ; director, Pascal Thomas ; writers, Pascal Thomas, Roland Duval ; photography, Colin Mounier ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Frederic Duru, Edmond Raillard, Jean-Marc Chollet, Daniel Ceccaldi, Serge Rousseau, Jacques Debary, Virginie Thevenet.

results.title: Les Vacances de Monsieur Hulot = Mister Hulot's Holidays
results.brief_description:
Monsieur Hulot arrives at a Brittany seaside resort, where he inadvertently sparks a chain reaction of mishaps. By the time his vacation is over, Hulot is the object of disdain for everyone at the resort, with the exception of two adults and a group of children. Like Max Linder, Chaplin and Keaton, he [Tati] was an actor-auteur, and like them his comic style, based on sight gags, was universally exportable … With his tall, ungainly figure, and his signature raincoat, hat and pipe, Tati made Hulot the universal child-like innocent who creates chaos by ignoring adult rules … But Tati’s novelty was to combine slapstick with a modernist sensitivity. Formally, his films are extremely complex (and increasingly so, explaining his loss of favor after ‘Mon oncle’), exploiting to the full the possibilities of the frame and sound … His soundtracks, mixing noises, grunts, expletives, advertisements, snatches of songs and different languages, are the aural equivalent of Jean-Luc Godard ‘visual bricolage’. From the start, too, Tati’s films were a running commentary on the struggle between modernisation (or ‘Americanisation’) and tradition in France. ‘Les vacances de Monsieur Hulot’ was Tati’s second feature film and the first appearance of Monsieur Hulot who was to feature in all of Tati’s subsequent films.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘The companion to French cinema’. BFI Publishing, 1996. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1953 ; Cannes Film Festival 1953-Prix de la Critique Internationale.

Credits: Producer, Fred Orain ; director, Jacques Tati ; script, Jacques Tati, Henri Marquet ; photography, Jacques Mercanton, Jean Mouselle ; music, Alain Romans.
Cast: Nathalie Pascaud, Michele Rolla, Raymond Carl, Lucien Fregis, Jacques Tati.

results.title: Les Trois Mousquetaires = the Three Musketeers (TV version)
results.brief_description:
In this live to air recording of the classic story by Alexandre Dumas, D’Artagnan, a young provincial noble, travels to Paris to join the musketeers. He meets action, love, hate, the king and the queen as his impetuousness gets him involved in political plots… and of course virile and indestructible friendship with the three musketeers Athos, Porthos and Aramis. A young Belmondo plays the dashing hero.

Credits: Director, Claude Barma ; writers, Claude Barma, Pierre Nivollet ; photography, Jacques Lemare ; music, Jean Marion.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Chevrier, Daniel Sorano, Hubert Noel, Gaby Sylvia, Pierre Asso, Michel Galabru, Georges Descrieres, Bernard Dheran, Robert Hirsch, Michel Galabru.

results.title: Les Revoltes de Lomanach = the Rebels of Lomanach
results.brief_description:
In Vendee (western France) in 1799, Barnaud invades the estate of Lomanach with a group of Republican soldiers. Before the Revolution Barnaud used to be the estate manager of Lomanach. Monique, daughter of the owner, attempts to seduce Barnaud in order to kill him and save the estate. ‘Les Revoltes de Lomanach’ was France’s first widescreen feature presentation. This version is presented in standard screen ratio 3:4.

Credits: Producer, Francois Chavanne ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jacques Sigurd, Leo Joannon ; photography, Jean Leherissey ; music, Georges van Parys ; assistant director, Claude Sautet ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Amedeo Nazzari, Dany Robin, Michel Vitold, Carla Del Poggio, Jacques Castelot, Jean Debucourt, Robert Dalban.

results.title: Les Olympiens = the Olympians
results.brief_description:
Vidocq has joined a pirate ship transporting 300 barrels of stolen rum. A wounded soldier gives Vidocq his ID papers and our man leaps at the chance to come back to France and reunite with Annette. Shortly after his arrival at the army barracks, Vidocq receives a mysterious invitation to attend a secret meeting of The Olympians Society.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Michel Charrel, Albert Dagnant, Maurice Garrel, Fred Personne.

results.title: Les Nouveaux Realistes
results.creator_credit: Adrian Maben, Michele Arnaud and Reiner Moritz
results.brief_description:
Profile of a group of artists trying to bring into their art the reality of urban and industrial landscapes. They include: Yves Klein, Arman, Cesar, Christo, Deschamps, Dufrene, Hains, Tinguely, Nikki de Saint Phalle.

Credits: Producers, Michele Arnaud, Reiner Moritz ; director, Adrian Maben.

results.title: Les Nations S'affirment
results.brief_description:
This episode deals with the slow movement of affirmation of regional styles as a sign of resistance against the ‘French gothic’. Sicily is a prime example of a country where the confluence of the Hellenic, Islamic and Latin inflences gives birth to a singular style, epitomized by the cathedral of Montreale (near Palermo). In Italy, Frederic II Hohenstauffen moves to reject both the Islamic and Byzantine influence as well as that of the French gothic. The Cathedral in Betonto (Italy) bears the strong influence of the Carolingian style in evidence in the Palatine chapel of Aachen (Germany).

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Les Miserables: Stage By Stage
results.creator_credit: John Caird, Trevor Nunn, Martin Cox and Telstar Independent Programs
results.brief_description: This film follows the development of the musical “Les Miserables” which has become a triumph the world over. When it opened in London in October 1985, at the Barbican Theatre, it opened to mixed reviews, but went on to silence the critics and is now one of the most successful musical shows of all time. “Les Miserables” is either in production or development in over seventy cities of the world. The success continues. A symphonic recording of the complete score is being released worldwide and a film version of the musical is in development. Using performance footage from the London, Oslo, Budapest and Viennese productions, this program celebrates this phenomenal success and discusses its progress with its writers, directors and producers.

results.title: Les Miserables (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Imprisoned for stealing a loaf of bread, Jean Valjean’s life is transformed by an act of forgiveness. He becomes the respected mayor of the poor town of Vigau and transforms it into a thriving community. He also falls in love with one of Vigau’s most pitiful, poverty-stricken residents, the beautiful Fantine, and devotes himself to her care.

Credits: Director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Marcel Bluwal ; photography, Andre Bac.
Cast: Bernard Fresson, Micha Bayard, Georges Geret, Nicole Jamet, Francois Marthouret, Alain Mottet.
